metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: DSA Selection Sort Time Complexity
See this page for a general explanation of what time complexity is.
content.html: See this page for a general explanation of what time complexity is.

content.text: Selection Sort Time Complexity
The Selection Sort algorithm goes through all elements in an array, finds the lowest value, and moves it to the front of the array, and does this over and over until the array is sorted.
content.html: The Selection Sort algorithm goes through all elements in an array, finds the lowest value, and moves it to the front of the array, and does this over and over until the array is sorted.

content.text: Selection Sort goes through an array of n n values n − 1 n − 1 times. This is because when the algorithm has sorted all values except the last, the last value must also be in its correct place.
content.html: Selection Sort goes through an array of nn values n−1n−1 times. This is because when the algorithm has sorted all values except the last, the last value must also be in its correct place.

content.text: The first time the algorithm runs through the array, every value is compared to find out which one is the lowest.
content.html: The first time the algorithm runs through the array, every value is compared to find out which one is the lowest.

content.text: The second time the algorithm runs through the array, every value except the first value is compared to find out which is the lowest.
content.html: The second time the algorithm runs through the array, every value except the first value is compared to find out which is the lowest.

content.text: And in this way the unsorted part of the array becomes shorter and shorter until the sorting is done. So on average, n 2 n 2 elements are considered when the algorithm goes through the array finding the lowest value and moving it to the front of the array.
content.html: And in this way the unsorted part of the array becomes shorter and shorter until the sorting is done. So on average, n2n2 elements are considered when the algorithm goes through the array finding the lowest value and moving it to the front of the array.

content.text: In addition to all the compares needed, the number of swaps needed is n n .
content.html: In addition to all the compares needed, the number of swaps needed is nn.

content.text: We can start calculating the number of operations for the Selection Sort algorithm:
content.html: We can start calculating the number of operations for the Selection Sort algorithm:

content.text: O p e r a t i o n s = ( n − 1 ) ⋅ n 2 + n = n 2 2 − n 2 + n = n 2 2 + n 2 O p e r a t i o n s = ( n − 1 ) ⋅ n 2 + n = n 2 2 − n 2 + n = n 2 2 + n 2
content.html: Operations=(n−1)⋅n2+n=n22−n2+n=n22+n2Operations=(n−1)⋅n2+n=n22−n2+n=n22+n2

content.text: When looking at the run time for algorithms, we look at very large data sets, meaning n n is a very big number. And for a very big number n n , the term n 2 2 n 2 2 becomes so much bigger than the term n 2 n 2 that we can approximate by simply removing that second term n 2 n 2 .
content.html: When looking at the run time for algorithms, we look at very large data sets, meaning nn is a very big number. And for a very big number nn, the term n22n22 becomes so much bigger than the term n2n2 that we can approximate by simply removing that second term n2n2.

content.text: O p e r a t i o n s = n 2 2 + n 2 ≈ n 2 2 = 1 2 ⋅ n 2 O p e r a t i o n s = n 2 2 + n 2 ≈ n 2 2 = 1 2 ⋅ n 2
content.html: Operations=n22+n2≈n22=12⋅n2Operations=n22+n2≈n22=12⋅n2

content.text: Using Big O notation to describe the time complexity for the Selection Sort algorithm, we get:
content.html: Using Big O notation to describe the time complexity for the Selection Sort algorithm, we get:
O(12⋅n2)=O(n2)––––––––––––––O(12⋅n2)=O(n2)__

content.text: And time complexity for the Selection Sort algorithm can be displayed in a graph like this:
content.html: And time complexity for the Selection Sort algorithm can be displayed in a graph like this:

content.text: As you can see, the run time is the same as for Bubble Sort: The run time increases really fast when the size of the array is increased.
content.html: As you can see, the run time is the same as for Bubble Sort: The run time increases really fast when the size of the array is increased.

content.text: Selection Sort Simulation
Run the simulation for different number of values in an array, and see how the number of operations Selection Sort needs on an array of n n elements is O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 ) :
content.html: Run the simulation for different number of values in an array, and see how the number of operations Selection Sort needs on an array of nn elements is O(n2)O(n2):

content.text: Set values: 300
content.html: 300

content.text: Random
Worst Case
Best Case
10 Random
Operations: 0
content.html: Operations: 0

content.text: The most significant difference from Bubble sort that we can notice in this simulation is that best and worst case is actually almost the same for Selection Sort ( O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 ) ), but for Bubble Sort the best case runtime is only O ( n ) O ( n ) .
content.html: The most significant difference from Bubble sort that we can notice in this simulation is that best and worst case is actually almost the same for Selection Sort (O(n2)O(n2)), but for Bubble Sort the best case runtime is only O(n)O(n).

content.text: The difference in best and worst case for Selection Sort is mainly the number of swaps. In the best case scenario Selection Sort does not have to swap any of the values because the array is already sorted. And in the worst case scenario, where the array already sorted, but in the wrong order, so Selection Sort must do as many swaps as there are values in the array.
content.html: The difference in best and worst case for Selection Sort is mainly the number of swaps. In the best case scenario Selection Sort does not have to swap any of the values because the array is already sorted. And in the worst case scenario, where the array already sorted, but in the wrong order, so Selection Sort must do as many swaps as there are values in the array.
